'''S&P Indices Versus Active (SPIVA®)''' are semiannual reports published by S&P Dow Jones Indices that compare the performance of active equity and fixed income mutual funds against their benchmarks over different time horizons.<ref name="spiva">{{Cite web|title=SPIVA® Scorecards: An Overview|url=https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/education/article/spiva-scorecards-an-overview/|date=2021-06-21|access-date=2025-06-24|website=S&P Dow Jones Indices}}</ref>
==Overview== Active management takes the approach that with enough skill, it’s easy to consistently outperform the market, or the benchmark. The SPIVA scorecard reports were created as a challenge to this claim.<ref name = "About">{{Cite web|title=About SPIVA|url=https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/about-spiva/|access-date=2025-06-24|website=S&P Dow Jones Indices}}</ref>
Certain themes have emerged over time. One is that actively managed funds have historically tended to underperform their benchmarks over short- and long-term periods. This has tended to hold true (with exceptions) across countries and regions.<ref name = "About" />
Another recurring theme is that even when a majority of actively managed funds in a category have outperformed the benchmark over one time period, they have usually failed to outperform over multiple periods.<ref name = "About" />
Relatively few active managers are able to outperform passive managers over any given time period, either short-term or long-term.<ref name = "About" />
Demonstrating the ability to outperform repeatedly is the only proven way to differentiate a manager's skill from luck. The scorecards show that relatively few funds can consistently stay at the top.<ref name = "About" />
First published in 2002 for the US, the scorecard has been extended to Australia, Canada, Europe, India, Japan, Latin America, South Africa, and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) regions.<ref name="spiva" />
==Reports== The SPIVA reports incorporate the following factors in measuring active fund performance.<ref name="spiva" />
# '''Survivorship bias correction:''' SPIVA removes funds that were liquidated or merged during a period of study. # '''Apples-to-apples comparison:''' Fund returns are compared to a benchmark that is appropriate for each particular fund's style and size category. # '''Equal- and Asset-weighted returns:''' SPIVA reports show both equal- and asset-weighted averages. # '''Style consistency:''' US and Canada SPIVA scorecards measure consistency for each style category across different time horizons. # '''Quartile Breakpoints:''' In each category, dispersion in fund returns across different time horizons highlight the fund selection risk that market participants face. # '''Data Cleaning''': SPIVA avoids double counting of multiple share classes in all count based calculations where only the share class with bigger assets is used. Index funds, leveraged and inverse funds, and other index-linked products are excluded since SPIVA is meant to be a scorecard for active managers.
Reports are available for the following regions:
* [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#us United States] * [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#canada Canada] * [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#mexico Mexico] * [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#brazil Brazil] * [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#chile Chile] * [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#europe Europe] * [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#mena Middle East and North Africa] (MENA) * [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#south-africa South Africa] * [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#japan Japan] * [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/research-insights/spiva/#australia Australia]
Each region can show historical performance for 1, 3, 5, 10, or 15 years.
A complete guide to the SPIVA scorecard reports, including interpretation of the report contents, can be found in [https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/documents/education/education-spiva-scorecards-an-overview.pdf SPIVA® Scorecards: An Overview].

'''[[FTSE Group|FTSE]]''' (Financial Times and Stock Exchange) publishes [[Free-float methodology|free-float]] [[market capitalization]] indexes of United Kingtom (UK) stocks. FTSE created its first index, the FT Actuaries All-Share Index, in 1962.The FT Actuaries All-Share Index was initially a price only index, excluding dividends. FTSE later added two new sub-indexes, the FTSE 100 in January 1984 and the FTSE 250 in October 1992. In 1993 the FTSE All-Share Index began reporting returns on total return basis. This index is now known as the FTSE-All-Share Index. FTSE also publishes gilt indexes.Gilts are bonds issued by the British government, and generally considered to be low risk. Gilts are the UK equivalent of US Treasury securities. There are two types of gilt: conventional; and inflation-linked. In December 2011, The London Stock Exchange (LSE) took complete ownership of FTSE.{{cite web| url=https://archive.nytimes.com/dealbook.nytimes.com/2011/12/12/london-stock-exchange-buys-remaining-stake-in-ftse/| title=L.S.E. Group to Buy Remainder of FTSE| publisher=The New York Times| accessdate=October 5, 2023}} ==FTSE stock market indexes== {{See also|Investing from the UK#Stocks|l1=Investing from the UK § Stocks}} The FTSE UK stock indexes{{cite web| url=https://www.ftserussell.com/products/indices/uk| title=FTSE UK Index Series | publisher=FTSE Russell| accessdate=October 5, 2023}} include: * [[wikipedia:FTSE All-Share Index|FTSE All-Share Index]]
This index represents 98-99% of UK market capitalisation, FTSE All-Share is the aggregation of the FTSE 100, FTSE 250 and FTSE Small Cap indexes. * [[wikipedia:FTSE 100 Index|FTSE 100 Index]]
This index (inception on January 3, 1984) comprises the 100 most highly capitalised blue chip companies, representing approximately 81% of the UK market. * [[wikipedia:FTSE 250 Index|FTSE 250 Index]]
This index (inception on October 12, 1992) comprises mid-capitalised companies not covered by the FTSE 100, and represents approximately 15% of UK market capitalisation. * [[wikipedia:FTSE 350 Index|FTSE 350 Index]]
This index is a combination of the FTSE 100 and FTSE 250 indexes. * [[wikipedia:FTSE SmallCap Index|FTSE SmallCap Index]]
The index consists of companies outside of the FTSE 350 Index and represents approximately 2% of the UK market capitalisation. * [[wikipedia:FTSE Fledgling Index|FTSE Fledgling Index]]
This index is for UK companies listed on the main market of the London Stock Exchange that are too small to be included in the FTSE All-Share. Index tracker funds commonly use the FTSE All-Share, FTSE 100, and FTSE 250 indexes. ==FTSE Gilt market indexes== {{See also|Investing from the UK#UK bonds|l1=Investing from the UK § UK bonds}} The FTSE UK Gilts indexes{{cite web| url=https://www.ftserussell.com/products/indices/gilts| title=FTSE Actuaries UK Gilts Index Series| publisher=FTSE Russell| accessdate=October 5, 2023}} include: {| | * FTSE Actuaries UK Conventional Gilts up to 5 Years * FTSE Actuaries UK Conventional Gilts up to 10 Years * FTSE Actuaries UK Conventional Gilts 5-15 Years * FTSE Actuaries UK Conventional Gilts over 15 Years * FTSE Actuaries UK Conventional Gilts All Stocks * British Government Over 25 Years | * British Government -Linked All Stocks * British Government -Linked up to 5 years * British Government -Linked Over 5 Years * FTSE Actuaries UK -Linked Gilts up to 10 Years * British Government -Linked 5 - 15 years * British Government -Linked Over 15 Years |} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="note"}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.londonstockexchange.com/indices FTSE Indices], London Stock Exchange *[https://www.dmo.gov.uk/responsibilities/gilt-market/about-gilts/ About Gilts], UK Debt Management Office {{Non-US domiciles}} [[Category:United Kingdom]] [[Category:FTSE indexes]]
